newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore cuts mobile licence fees.
newsitem.headline: Singapore cuts mobile licence fees.

text.p: SINGAPORE, April 1, Reuter - Singapore marked the deregulation of its mobile phone and paging markets on Tuesday by scrapping licence fees for all cellular telephones and hand-held radio transmitters.

Communications Minister Mah Bow Tan told a ceremony to launch one of the island's three new paging services that the move would save portable phone users between Singapore $50 and S$100 a year in licence fees.
Total savings would be around S$23 million a year, he said.
"This move, together with the new competition regime, will make mobile telecommunication services even more accessible to users," Mah said.
He said the Telecommunications Authority of Singapore (TAS) was striving to cut the cost of telecommunications services in Singapore.
TAS said in a statement the move would affect around 440,000 mobile phone users, 1,100 mobile data system users and 12,000 trunked radio users.
From Tuesday, Singapore's mobile phone and paging markets were opened to competition for the first time.

The island's majority state-owned Singapore Telecommunications Ltc (SingTel) lost its complete monopoly and faced one competitor, MobileOne, in the mobile phone market and three new rival pager services.
Mah was officiating at the launch of Sunpage, a unit of state-owned conglomerate Singapore Technologies Group.
MobileOne is a joint venture of Britain's Cable & Wireless, Hong Kong Telecommunications, Keppel Telecom and Singapore Press Holdings.

Tan Guong Ching, the chairman of Singapore Technologies Telemedia (STT), said his company hoped to be successful in its bid for a full basic telecommunications licence in Singapore when that market is opened in April 2000.
STT has joined with state-owned utility Singapore Power, British Telecommunications plc and Nippon Telephone and Telegraph (NTT) to bid for a licence.
